document.title: Washington, DC K-12 Social Studies Standards Revised Standards

1BA593DA53494C51BCCFFA5BDB0F0053.description:
Using evidence, construct a claim about a compelling question regarding a UNESCO World Heritage Site or the
ownership of artifacts from antiquity.

2DAB8EED208A439F89FCECCC888A4D6C.description:
Apply sourcing information, such as authorship, point of view, purpose, intended audience, and historical context to
primary and secondary sources to evaluate the credibility of source materials.

9F384F642ECF457CB6AE15A3F2D94171.description: Evaluate the credibility of online sources and claims about UNESCO World Heritage Sites or ownership of artifacts.

42C465AEE33F4DB49EA61EAE6EAE1F03.description: Identify a compelling question related to the UNESCO World Heritage List or the ownership of artifacts from antiquity.

D73B07974B9A4E45932D25779BB60758.description:
Through this driving concept of World History I, students will demonstrate the questioning, analysis, and communication skills
developed during the elementary, middle school, and high school social studies program. Students will develop compelling
questions, plan an inquiry, evaluate sources, gather evidence, and communicate conclusions to an audience.

CE733395A9774B4385F0ED8834DC626F.description:
Explain the causes and effects of technological innovations and early urbanization on societies in Asia, Europe, Africa, and
the Americas between 1000 CE and 1600 CE.

40FAA3C968BB413DA1EF82D8AEF8815C.description:
Analyze the development of institutions of higher education and intellectual centers and assess their role in advancing
societies between 1000 CE and 1600 CE.

C160DE90D5C54BFC910635840C1CD73B.description:
Analyze the roles of men of women in different societies, including ways in which women exercised power between 1000
CE and 1600 CE.

5C8F7DCE03F14882A501B0B6A70E76DF.description:
Compare and contrast how states and empires in Asia, the Americas, Africa, and Europe addressed issues of cultural
diversity, religious diversity, and conflict within their societies, including an analysis of the rise of Sikhism between 1000 CE and
1600 CE.

E9CA48A00E5C452BA769BA7F44E703C2.description:
Analyze the impact of centralizing power on both trade and conflict between and within states and empires in Asia,
Europe, Africa and the Americas between 1000 CE and 1600 CE.

64C3A072809C40C78A233310DDD3A6F1.description:
Compare and contrast the methods rulers used to legitimize and consolidate power within Asia, Europe, Africa, and the
Americas, including bureaucracies, religion, militarism, feudalism, architecture, taxation, and art between 1000 CE and 1600 CE.

E75C97173FD64A669DA385BEABB35F5B.description:
Analyze the factors that contributed to the expansion and/or emergence of powerful nation-states and empires in Asia,
Europe, Africa, and the Americas between 1000 CE and 1600 CE.

EAB08DF6BAA6424EB69779B5B9AA8085.description:
Evaluate the credibility and perspectives of different sources in understanding Ancient Empires and use them to answer
specific questions about societies between 1000 CE and 1600 CE.

052F054A729C450E874EA275451D6794.description:
In this driving concept, students will analyze the development of nation-states and early modern empires and analyze the
methods that empires used to centralize power and expand globally. Students will study the roots of imperialism and
colonialism, to deepen their understanding of global power dynamics as well as lay the foundation for the World History II
course. Teachers should choose at least one society from each region to explore as case studies. Societies of focus can include:Africa: Songhai, Mali, Great Zimbabwe, Asante, Zulu
Americas: Inca, Aztec (Mexica), TainosAsia: Song Dynasty, Mongols (Yuan Dynasty), Delhi Sultanate, Safavid Empire, Ottoman Empire
Europe: England, Spain, France, Holy Roman Empire, Byzantine Empire
Australia and Oceania: Maori, Aboriginals

859F0A76231B4977A9D596023E60CE93.description: Driving Concept 5: Early Modern Empires (1000 CE-1600 CE)

D79CAA06B5454BE7B414327921AB505B.description:
Evaluate the impact of intellectual and technological innovations from Asia on the development of societies in Africa and
Europe between 400-1200 CE.

81DD2650E6D1443F80A0C644733E4624.description:
Evaluate the economic, political, religious, cultural, and social impacts of population and cultural diffusion in Africa, Asia,
the Americas, and Europe due to trade, military expansion, and migration between 400-1200 CE.

26430570817C4158B5A3127A88697472.description:
Analyze the roles of men and women in different societies, including ways in which women exercised power, between
400-1200 CE.

2E85224BE5AC44DEB00BC90DAE8B053B.description:
Use maps to analyze the emergence of major networks of exchange (trade routes) between 400-1200 CE, including the
role of specific goods and commodities and technology.

6E212B7246B34A8AB289611D608A9DBD.description:
Explain the ways geography influenced the development of economic, political, religious, and cultural centers in Africa,
Asia, the Americas, and Europe and how the centers facilitated population and cultural diffusion between 400-1200 CE.

C50740694E514CA086B720B8E6D095C4.description:
Analyze the role of religion, belief systems, and culture in the governance and maintenance of societies in Africa, Asia,
and Europe between 400-1200 CE.

FC4962B4183846DCA6BF086A3DA29643.description:
Analyze the social and cultural changes and continuities between ancient empires and their successors in the same place
between 400-1200 CE.

F91C6BE15C764F9294E5149F09E3DECB.description:
Analyze the political changes and continuities in the societies and dynasties that emerged after the decline of ancient
empires in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Americas between 400-1200 CE.

5809129CEE30418D98F81148CFEBB5B5.description: Use maps to analyze the decline of ancient empires and emergence of new empires from 400-1200 CE.

97AE5E66DE08494DBAC0D0ECF341C1B2.description:
In this driving concept, students continue to use social, political, cultural, and economic lenses to analyze the emergence of new
empires and societies, including how these empires interacted to cause each others’ success and decline. Students will analyze
patterns of trade, war, migration, and cultural diffusion to analyze global power dynamics. Teachers can choose at least one
society from each different region to explore as case studies. Societies of focus can include:Africa: Ghana, Hausa Kingdoms, Ethiopian Empire
Americas: Pueblo, Maya, Teotihuacan, Moche
Asia: Sui, Tang, and Song dynasties in China, Gurjara-Pratihara Dynasty, Umayyad Caliphate, Heian Period in Japan
Europe: Frankish Empire (France), England (Anglo-Saxon kingdoms), Byzantine Empire, Holy Roman Empire
Australia and Oceania: Polynesia

20B7A90A1D5C454BBA344AD3B7D0DAA1.description:
Driving Concept 4: Reorganization of Societies and Increasing Networks of Exchange
(400-1200 CE)

74FDF697BF374B5588CF64400A689A55.description:
Evaluate the social, political, cultural, and economic factors that led to the decline of various ancient empires between
800 BCE and 700 CE.

82051E0C48404951B432E60716A195A0.description:
Analyze the effects of new long-distance trade networks on the collaboration and conflict between empires between 800
BCE and 700 CE.

33887963069049F8ADE8B06E0D26A514.description:
Analyze the emergence of complex, interregional networks of trade throughout Afro-Eurasia and how trade networks led
to the diffusion and evolution of ideas, resources, and technologies between 800 BCE and 700 CE.

A409BD1EEA4E49F8ACE84A54029616A2.description:
Analyze the differences among gender roles during this time, including the role of women in different societies and the
ways in which women exercised power between 800 BCE and 700 CE.

E54C208DC593427E993BA0955151979A.description:
Analyze archaeological evidence and primary sources to compare the rights of individuals in different ancient empires
between 800 BCE and 700 CE.

C9935D9AB65E4EC68E8C5701CE795339.description:
Compare and contrast social hierarchies of ancient empires in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Americas and the ideologies
that guided them between 800 BCE and 700 CE.

C3F8F81E700E4FC2A06F321222F1E3B6.description:
Assess the importance and enduring legacy of major governmental, technological, religious, and cultural achievements of
ancient empires in Europe, Asia, the Americas, and Africa between 800 BCE and 700 CE.

29A815BC91114CFC9F2A3848AD53A870.description: Analyze the ways in which ancient empires in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Americas, were governed, including decisionmaking, means of promoting the common good, and the relationship between people and their government 800 BCE and 700 CE.

ABD92C59C88C41DD8E08A5111834E523.description:
Compare the emergence of empires across Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Americas including their methods of
consolidating and maintaining power between 800 BCE and 700 CE.

B01334D6374D4F519EC8B2D76332486B.description:
Compare and contrast the tenets of various belief systems that developed in ancient empires and how they spread,
including Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, Judaism, Hinduism, and Confucianism.

6DE3AC38E7084404A202A544663066CA.description:
Evaluate the credibility and perspectives of different sources in understanding Ancient Empires and use them to answer
specific questions about societies between 800 BCE and 700 CE.

09494BE27212462B99FE93A269B41E0D.description:
In this driving concept, students will begin to analyze the social, political, cultural, religious, and economic traits of societies to
understand how humans of the past interacted with each other and with their environment to create complex civilizations.
Students will trace the rise of historical empires and evaluate their legacy on our present world. Teachers should choose at least
one society from each region to explore as case studies. Societies of focus can include:Africa: Aksum, Carthage, Nok
Asia: Han China, Persia, Mauryan and Gupta (India), Akkadians and Assyrians
Americas: The Maya
Europe: Greece, Rome

C99D76F24DAA40498EF87B31F789A01E.description: Driving Concept/Topic #3: Ancient Empires (800 BCE to 700 CE)

857E7A71BD31426B8555FE32106D5EFA.description:
Compare and contrast the reasons for the decline of complex agrarian societies in Asia, Africa, and the Americas between
10,000 BCE and 500 BCE.

4CB45191D8D2430A919F471898C932A0.description:
Analyze archeological and primary source materials to make a claim about daily life for different individuals within Africa,
Asia, and the Americas between 10,000 BCE and 500 BCE.

C91597A96E304352819C7D4B83A38958.description:
Compare the role of women in different societies, including ways in which women exercised power between 10,000 BCE
and 500 BCE.

0085FE26493C44F6940A57512A66CF74.description:
Analyze how early religions and belief systems shaped the political, legal, economic, and social structure of states in
Africa, Asia, and the Americas between 10,000 BCE and 500 BCE.

C6D3AC21F35D4A2A9D3710D54514E609.description:
Explain how the development of cities in Africa, Asia, Europe, and the Americas led to common characteristics of early
complex societies including social hierarchies, governments and laws, specialization, and writing between 10,000 BCE and 500
BCE.

95A28766A0BA439E9FEADD4A87592D6E.description:
Analyze the role of agricultural, technological, and cultural innovations in the emergence and maintenance of early
complex societies between 10,000 BCE and 500 BCE.

9C7FDCF9D6D649C8B929E6AD1B780089.description:
Locate and explain the significance of specific landforms and bodies of water of early complex societies in different
regions between 10,000 BCE and 500 BCE.

AD96F336A67346129EE2182DC43A73DB.description:
Analyze the geographical and environmental factors that encouraged human communities to organize into complex
states and adopt approaches to procure resources including pastoral nomadism and other non-agricultural approaches.

CEE245E9E1AB49869B4E9C03B1C135BE.description:
Analyze the values and limits of different archeological evidence in reconstructing the early history of domestication and
agricultural settlement.

49C30D801F4240A5AEAC9FA256F0BD83.description: Explain how historians categorize time periods and the strengths and limitations of periodization.

8FF7DA5452D343E3B800EF689E7FF633.description:
This driving concept builds upon students’ understanding of ways to study historical evidence and make meaning from the past
to analyze how societies arose, first in Africa, then in Asia, and the Americas. Students will analyze geographic and environmental
factors that promoted human societies, as well as how humans developed skills and technology to become complex, successful,
agrarian societies. Then, students will analyze how these societies created and were shaped by early cultural traits and belief
systems. Teachers should choose at least one of the following societies of focus from each region to explore as case studies.
Societies of focus can include:Africa: Kush, Nubia, EgyptThe Americas: The Olmecs, Maya, Norte Chico (Peru)Asia: Mesopotamia, Jericho, China (the Shang Dynasty), Indus Valley

D46C708ABD2442C7A98374C1B4D8F2D4.description: Driving Concept 2: Early Societies and Cities (10,000 BCE to 500 BCE)

BFB7E6563E9C43C1812FE55646EECBF7.description:
Analyze possible links between environmental conditions associated with the last Ice Age and changes in the economy,
culture, and organization of human communities.

5B614E59EF314274BE58F46DECF165DE.description:
Analyze archaeological evidence to understand the characteristics of early complex belief systems, including widespread
worship of female deities.

3CE69A8500E946EA82D7AEA520E5B759.description: Evaluate the effects of different approaches to gathering resources (foraging and farming) that emerged during this era.

6F03197EAC5A47E697DE55C2086F1157.description: Analyze Paleolithic and Mesolithic art, tools, and artifacts to describe early human cultures.

C2C419928B67438C855E2E48576B8D7D.description: Analyze the impact of Paleolithic technological advances on early human evolution, migration, and communities.

63D1F02AEBF849F9BF3340570B12E4A2.description:
Evaluate how early humans adapted to different environments and how their presence shaped their environments over
time.

AF57D17684F64117B743BFDDCFD56B28.description:
Integrate evidence from multiple disciplines (e.g., genetics, archeology, anthropology, linguistics) to trace early human
migration from Africa to other major world regions.

00E7D6DDFBEE4DF8AF5419661FA8A0C4.description:
Analyze the scientific and archeological evidence to understand the interactions between Homo sapiens and other species
of humans. (e.g., Homo neanderthalensis, Homo erectus, and Homo floresiensis.)

FB499D036A114406A9967DD981D79202.description:
Describe types of evidence and methods of investigation that anthropologists, archaeologists, and other scholars have
used to reconstruct early human evolution and cultural development.

2D21DBC58FE74DB3ADE9CE309BFA4D33.description: Analyze the scientific and archeological evidence for hominin evolution from the Australopithecines to Homo sapiens.

9A57E9EB0F5A444684726B45DC9FBE64.description:
Through this driving concept, students acquire key historical thinking skills necessary for grappling with world history content
from the beginnings of human history through today. Students will evaluate how historians have traditionally organized history
using time, place, and historical milestones and human achievement based on available evidence, and also consider how the
available evidence gives rise to more questions than answers about the past. Students will explore the origins of communities
and ways of life to set the foundation for their study of the development of societies.

875111AEF2A54612A2C1F20E4D9031C9.description: Driving Concept 1: Beginnings of Human Communities (Up to 8000 BCE)
